p: Most importantly, the effectiveness of adaptation pivots on reducing levels of poverty and inequities, especially in women and other vulnerable groups. Simply put: if an individual’s or household’s socio-economic status is robust, they will have a greater ability to withstand shocks induced by climate change. In South Africa, however, about a quarter of the population are unemployed and over half live below the poverty line [ 28]. Poverty reduction initiatives, such as the highly successful social grants system [ 29], thus lie at the heart of health adaptation. These initiatives already reach 17.5 million vulnerable people in South Africa [ 30], could be further extended to counter balance the disproportionate effects of climate change on vulnerable groups [ 31]. Equally, having a resilient health system is central to effective climate change adaptation.
